citation.article-title: Lactobacillus gasseri sp. nov., a new species of the subgenus Thermobacterium.
citation.source: Zentralblatt für Bakteriologie, Mikrobiologie und Hygiene.

p.s: Description of Lactobacillus gasseri sp. nov.
Lactobacillus gasseri (gas.ser'i. M.L. gen. noun gasser of Gasser, named for Francis Gasser, who pioneered studies on lactate dehydrogenases of Lactobacillus species)
Rods with rounded ends, generally 0.6-0.8 by 3.0-5 μm occurring singly and in chains.
Frequent formation of "mini cells" and snakes.
Non-motile.
Non-flagellated. - Colony usually rough and flat.
No characteristic pigment.
Growth of blood-free agar streak cultures is greatly enhanced by anaerobiosis and 5% CO2. - Obligately saccharoclastic.
Glucose, fructose, sucrose, cellobiose, and salicin regularly fermented.
Variable reactions with lactose, maltose, trehalose, raffinose, and melibiose.
Mannitol rarely fermented.
Reactions negative on pentoses, rhamnose, inositol, sorbitol, and inulin.
Homofermentative, producing DL-lactic acid. - Ammonia not produced from arginine.
Milk coagulated with rare exceptions.
Indole, H2, lipase, lecithinase or urease not produced.
No digestion of gelatin or milk. - No growth below 22°C; growth generally at 45°C; optimum at 35-38°C.
Growth occurs at initial pH values of 5-7; optimum 5.5-6.0. - Murein is of the L-lysine-D-aspartic acid type.
In contrast with other lactobacilli, the D-ala-D-ala termini of the peptide subunits are preserved because of the lack of D,D-carboxypeptidase action.
Cell wall teichoic acid not detectable.
Cell walls contain high levels of glucose (about 1 μMole per mg cell wall), and smaller amounts of galactose but no pentoses or rhamnose. - The G + C content of the DNA is 34 moles% (Tm).
Habitat: Mouth, intestines, faces, and vagina of juvenile or adult man.
Type strain: DSM 20243 (= 63 AM Gasser).
